metadata.title: JukeBox by OpenAI.. The Charme of AI-generated Music (with… | by Merzmensch | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: If you listen very carefully, you will hear them: the sounds from another world. I hear them. Well, not directly, but using JukeBox. JukeBox is a Neural Network that generates music, a project…

all_paragraphs: If you listen very carefully, you will hear them: the sounds from another world. I hear them. Well, not directly, but using JukeBox.

JukeBox is a Neural Network that generates music, a project, realized by the OpenAI team. They developed the neural framework and trained it on 1.2 million songs and music pieces by various musicians, composers, and bands.
There are already various approaches and AI-driven models generating music out there, but till now they were rather capable of creating some melodies in a MIDI quality.
This music piece, for example, I created using Piano Transformer from TensorFlow powered Magenta Framework (try it out: Colab Notebook)

Piano Transformer uses, like a transformer in GPT-3 the self-attention, which brings some inner coherence into the melody, with rather algorithmic tension (well, JS Bach created his Fugues also with algorithms).

JukeBox uses a transformer but has another approach: sampling — and upsampling — of audio data. It does mean, this music model “knows” how various styles and voices sound — and writes its interpretations. As audio files.
I wrote about JukeBox and other music models in my tutorial about making podcasts using AI:
In this article, I want to share with you some astonishing discoveries I made.
There is a breathtaking moment in the Series “DEVS”, as the scientists get a clearer and clearer vision of the Impossible — with every iteration they can see better and better the Unbelievable.
Using JukeBox you can experience a similar sensation. There is an official Colab Notebook you can use.

But there is also a Colab Notebook, enhanced by SMarioMan, (GitHub). It allows you to store your data on your Google Drive — in case your Notebook might crash. Because you need time for generating music — up to 8–10 hours.
Here is a very useful video tutorial by Broccaloo about using JukeBox:
First, you need to define an artist and genre. You can find all artists and genres JukeBox was trained on in the huge Playlist of AI-generated music by OpenAI here:
Second, a couple of samples are generated (3 items per default), within 10–30 minutes (Level 2). If you don’t like it, you can rerun it.

Third, the samples you’re OK with are generated — upscaled (Level 1 and Level 0). It takes time, sometimes half of a day. Sometimes Notebook crashes (connection interruptions, Google Server issues, etc. etc.). But if you use the Notebook by SMarioMan, all your progress is stored in your mounted GoogleDrive — and you can continue with the checkpoints saved there.
What can you do with Colab Notebook else? You can…

Meanwhile, we can observe very interesting results. Follow Leonardo Gutiérrez, who experiments a lot with JukeBox. Using our common re-writing of the AC/DC lyrics he generated a new version of “Shot in the Dark”:
Brocalloo (who did a very helpful video tutorial above) does also interesting experiments:
There is even a fan community of JukeBox users on Discord:

What fascinates me the most on JukeBox? Not quite the imitation of existing performers or interpretation of famous pieces — but the discovery of hidden gems. The musical hallucination of the machine. Unique soundscapes.
Uncanny Valley is a passé. It isn’t a weird or creepy feeling anymore — it’s the bliss of encountering artificial aesthetics.

Indeed, the works are unique: every time a new never before existed music piece is generated — and you can be sure (like in the case of GPT-3) that this sequence will never be repeated. It’s just for you. Only now and here.
My first experiment brought me goosebumps. Already the 2nd level was something special, not really in a way of music pieces. And the more upsampling it did, the more fascinating and clear it became:
It sounds… weird. Like a soundtrack to documentation about an unknown country with an unknown culture.
Indeed, JukeBox mimes language perfectly. It can interpret text you pre-set, but it also generates a musical interpretation of a language.
You can compare it with StyleGAN2 interpreting visuals of writing instead of its semantics:

Call it Brut Art, call it Glitch Art, but some of the audio samples generated by JukeBox are unbelievably intense. Here are just some of my favorites — and I am very eager to know your opinion about it?

Along with the cineast soundtrack above, I have several music pieces especially impacting my interest. Forget for a moment Machine Learning and theory. Just close your eyes, listen to music, and keep attention to various audio phenomena. I recommend using headphones for the best experience.

JukeBox is great for Jazz. Especially freestyle or experimental pieces full of syncopes and modulations. The first piece above is also delivered with a voice — you can recognize words, you also hear its imitation of English, but that is the only imitation. The second recording has an inspiring Big Band vibe as well — the sound quality of instruments is overwhelming.

Phenomenon: Another exciting phenomenon you observe here — most of the generated music pieces have finished composition. They don’t just end abruptly on the second you’ve set up for the music lengths (not all of them at least). The same Music Transformer making melody coherent work often enables the elegant music ending.
Listen to this acoustic guitar — you even can hear guitar string scratches, as if not only music is generated here, but also a musician.

Phenomenon: In the sample above you will observe (0:27 min) some sharp tone as if somebody is clapping. Just two times — and the melody rhythms are aligned from now to this clapping. The transformer transforms the music without disrupting its acoustical esthetics.
This is something special: close your eyes, and you will imagine a stage with actors, their performance, and even the audience’s reaction.

Phenomenon: what do you imagine listening to this piece? I almost see a hilarious King entering with fanfares (accompanied to audience’s laughter), then after some Tchaikovsky’s samples a love song follows (the ending with the protagonist singing “to you!..” [he probably kneels before his Lady]) — and the public cannot hide its emotions with enthusiastic applause, laughter, whistling. A very organic and realistic vision of a non-existent theater performance.
This piece was trained on Marissa Nadler, but at the beginning, a girl's voice sings in a non-existent language. After the solo, the powerful music begins, and the fragile voice becomes vigorous.
Phenomenon: the intensity, echo, and atmosphere were overwhelming. I used TokkingHeads service by RoseBud.AI (which implements i.a. First Order Motion Model) to visualize this performance:
Observation: JukeBox generates unique styles and languages, which can help with new surprising ideas and inspiration for musicians and composers.
In these two versions, I have chosen Tracy Chapman as a performer. The text was written for me by GPT-3:
And it works — distinctive voice by Tracy singing AI-generated lyrics (and I am in love with this GPT-3 poem).

Phenomenon: Like in other AI-generated songs, even if you specify lyrics for singing, it isn’t obvious that AI will obey and use your text for its song. Sometimes — even often — it augments the text with additional language glitches. Such unexpected and individual randomness proves again, that AI as a creative instance is certainly capable of more than just some algorithmic music prediction methods.

For this song, I trained JukeBox on the Nursery Rhyme “Row Row Row your Boat” and Jamie Cullum as a performer. Again, you can not only hear the text of the famous rhymes, but also some language glitches.

Phenomenon: not only the jazzy soundtrack and powerful miasma of the voice impressed me in this case. But also non-intended, but perfectly realized ellipsis: “merely, merely, merely, merely”… and the boat is floating into a sea of light.
Observation: Jukebox can give us interesting ideas of musical metaphors.
Btw. this is another version of “Row your boat”, which sounds rather like a jazzy Cold War love song in the meaning of “From Russia with Love”:

This musical piece sounds astonishing — it begins with experimental orchestra sounds, brutal and sharp shakuhachi or saxophone tones, other instruments take part in the cacophony, but then a harmonical chorus emerges.
If I hadn’t got this music delivered by JukeBox Notebook, I’d assume it was some music masterpiece from the Audio section of UbuWeb.

Phenomenon: Trained on Jamie Cullum, but in the “Classic Music” genre brings interesting and unique results — the training base is not recognizable anymore. Mixing aspects can cause surprising effects.
If you want to hear more: tune in to my daily #LatentVoices channel — or check out my #JukeBoxed-Playlist on Soundcloud.
Or generate your music and share it with us here.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Futurist. AI-driven Dadaist. Living in Germany, loving Japan, AI, mysteries, books, and stuff.
